content.introduction:
Ready to Act: Embodying Christ in the Digital Age," the final module of our Foundations for Christians and Technology course. As we conclude this journey, we stand at a pivotal moment—where our faith intersects with the immense power and potential of modern technology.  
Throughout this course, we've explored the complex landscape of digital innovation through the lens of our Christian faith. We've grappled with the challenges posed by exponential technological growth and examined how we, as followers of Christ, are called to respond. Now, we turn our attention to action—to the practical ways we can embody our faith in the digital realm and shape technology to reflect the values of God's Kingdom.  
Recall Jesus' words in Matthew 5:13-16:  
"You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its saltiness, how can it be made salty again? It is no longer good for anything, except to be thrown out and trampled underfoot. You are the light of the world. A town built on a hill cannot be hidden. Neither do people light a lamp and put it under a bowl. Instead they put it on its stand, and it gives light to everyone in the house. In the same way, let your light shine before others, that they may see your good deeds and glorify your Father in heaven."  
As Christians in the digital age, we are called to be salt and light in the vast expanse of cyberspace, in the algorithms that shape our online experiences, and in the technologies that are reshaping our world. Our faith compels us not to retreat from these challenges, but to engage them with wisdom, courage, and love.  
In this module, we will:

Synthesize the insights we've gained, viewing them through the prism of our Christian faith  
Explore how we can actively steward technology as an expression of our discipleship  
Learn to tell our stories of faith and technology, inspiring others to join in this crucial work  
Discover ways to build and engage with communities that share our vision  
Envision a future where technology serves God's purposes for humanity and creation

As we embark on this final stage of our journey, let us remember the words of James 1:22: "Do not merely listen to the word, and so deceive yourselves. Do what it says." Our calling is not just to understand, but to act—to be doers of the Word in the digital world.  
Let us move forward with hope, knowing that even as technology presents unprecedented challenges, it also offers extraordinary opportunities to extend Christ's love, justice, and redemption to every corner of our interconnected world. May this module equip and inspire you to be a faithful steward of technology, a beacon of Christ's light in the digital age, and a co-creator with God in shaping a more humane technological future.
content.conclusion:
Ready to Act \- Embodying Christ in the Digital Age  
As we conclude this Foundations for Christians and Technology course, we stand at the threshold of a new era—one where our faith and our technological future intersect in profound ways. Throughout our journey, we've explored the challenges and opportunities presented by exponential technology, always viewing them through the lens of our Christian faith and calling.  
We began by recognizing the urgency of our moment—a time when technology's power to shape our world has never been greater, and when the need for wisdom, discernment, and Christ-centered action has never been more critical. We've grappled with complex issues, from the ethics of AI to the impact of social media on our communities and our souls. We've sought to understand how we can be faithful stewards of technology, using it to glorify God and serve our neighbors.  
Now, as we complete this final "Ready to Act" module, we are called to move beyond understanding to action. Remember the words of James 1:22, "Do not merely listen to the word, and so deceive yourselves. Do what it says." Our learning must translate into living—into tangible changes in how we develop, use, and shape technology.  
Like Noah building the ark, we are called to a task that may seem daunting. The digital world often feels like a flood threatening to overwhelm us. But we build and act in faith, knowing that God has prepared us for such a time as this. We are planting seeds of change that may not bear fruit immediately, but which have the potential to transform our digital landscape.  
As you leave this course:

Carry with you the vision of technology aligned with Kingdom values—technology that promotes human dignity, fosters genuine community, and points toward our Creator.  
Commit to being "salt and light" in your digital engagements, whether you're a tech professional, a parent navigating your family's screen time, or a church leader considering how to use digital tools for ministry.  
Stay connected with the community you've built here. The challenges we face require collective wisdom and mutual support.  
Continue to cultivate a "digital discipleship"—habits of tech use and development that reflect Christ's teachings and character.  
Be prepared for opportunities that may arise from current and future tech crises. Like redwoods germinating after a fire, your faithful presence and action can bring new life to seemingly desolate digital landscapes.  
Remain grounded in prayer and Scripture, allowing God's word to continually renew your mind and guide your actions in the fast-paced world of technology.

Remember, you are not alone in this endeavor. You are part of a growing movement of Christians committed to shaping technology for God's glory and human flourishing. Your actions, no matter how small they may seem, contribute to a larger tapestry of redemptive work in the digital realm.  
As we close, let us recall the words of the apostle Paul in Colossians 3:23-24: "Whatever you do, work at it with all your heart, as working for the Lord, not for human masters, since you know that you will receive an inheritance from the Lord as a reward. It is the Lord Christ you are serving."  
Go forth, then, as digital disciples—ready to act, equipped to serve, and prepared to lead in creating a more humane, just, and Christ-centered technological future. May your work in technology be a testament to God's creative power and redemptive love, bringing light to the digital world and drawing others toward the ultimate source of that light—Jesus Christ.  
Let us pray:  
Heavenly Father, as we conclude this course, we thank you for the wisdom and insights you've granted us. We ask for your guidance as we step out to apply what we've learned. Give us courage to act boldly, humility to serve selflessly, and discernment to navigate the complex digital landscape before us. May our work in technology always point to You, the source of all wisdom and the author of our salvation. In Jesus' name, Amen.

## Ready To Act: Embodying Christ in the Digital Age

### Day

12.0

### Objective

8.0

### Foundations of Humane Tech Concepts Review

Ready to Act

1\. Recap of Previous Modules  
\- Brief review of key takeaways from each module, reinforcing core concepts of humane technology

2\. Call to Action  
\- Emphasizing the need for change in the technology industry  
\- Encouraging participants to act on their learning and drive paradigm shift

3.Spirit of Service and Learning  
\- Importance of approaching change with a service mindset and openness to learning

4\. Steps for Changing the Culture of Technology  
\- Telling your personal story  
\- Finding collaborators who share your vision

\- Overview of resources available to course participants

\- Introduction to partner organizations in the humane technology ecosystem  
\- Resources for different roles and career stages in tech

7\. Mind the Gap Exercise  
\- Revisiting the alignment between personal values and actions  
\- Encouraging ongoing reflection and adjustment

8\. Future of Humane Technology  
\- Analogy of redwoods germinating after a fire, relating to opportunities arising from tech crises  
\- Encouragement to plant seeds of change and be prepared for future opportunities

Continuing Engagement  
Information on course completion and certification  
Opportunities for further learning and involvement with the Center for Humane Technology

### Foundations of Christians and Technology Learning Objectives

Articulate how key concepts from each module align with Christian teachings and values  
Develop a cohesive Christian framework for engaging with and shaping technology

Recognize the biblical mandate for Christians to be salt and light in the digital world

Christlike Service in Tech  
Apply Jesus' model of servant leadership to technological innovation and use  
Cultivate a spirit of humility and continuous learning in tech engagement

Building Kingdom-Oriented Tech Culture  
Craft a personal testimony of faith informing tech choices and development  
Identify and connect with like-minded Christians in technology fields  
Implement small-scale tech projects that demonstrate Christ-centered values  
Redefine tech success through the lens of Kingdom impact and human flourishing

Christian Tech Community  
Engage with Christian tech networks and resources for ongoing growth and support  
Contribute to the formation of Christ-centered tech communities

Ecumenical and Interfaith Collaboration  
Explore partnerships with diverse faith-based and secular organizations in humane tech  
Understand the unique contributions Christians can make to the broader humane tech movement

Aligning Values and Actions  
Conduct a spiritual and technological audit of personal and church practices  
Develop strategies for ongoing discernment and adjustment in tech use and development

Christian Vision for Tech Futures  
Apply biblical hope and resurrection principles to tech crisis opportunities  
Envision and articulate a prophetic, Kingdom-oriented future for technology

Continued Growth and Engagement  
Plan for ongoing learning and spiritual formation in relation to technology  
Commit to active participation in shaping a more humane, Christ-centered tech landscape

### Introduction

In the same way, let your light shine before others, that they may see your good deeds and glorify your Father in heaven."

Matthew 5:13-16 \- Salt and light of the world

### Story 

The story of Noah and the Ark (Genesis 6-9) provides a powerful biblical parallel to the redwood analogy and aligns well with our learning objectives. Here's a narrative that reframes and builds on this calling:  
"In the days of Noah, God saw that the wickedness of humanity had grown great on the earth. The world was corrupt and filled with violence. Sound familiar? In our digital age, we too face a flood – not of water, but of information, misinformation, and technology that often seems to bring out the worst in humanity.  
But God didn't abandon the world. Instead, He called Noah to build an ark – a seemingly impossible task that required immense faith, patience, and perseverance. Noah's obedience in constructing the ark amidst ridicule and skepticism mirrors our calling as Christians in tech. We too are called to build – not physical arks, but digital spaces and technologies that preserve and promote human dignity, truth, and godly values.  
Just as the flood waters eventually receded, revealing a cleansed earth ready for new life, we anticipate that current tech crises will eventually subside. And like Noah, who planted a vineyard in the new world, we are called to plant seeds of change in the post-crisis digital landscape.  
The olive branch brought back by the dove symbolizes hope and new beginnings. In the same way, each small win we achieve in creating more humane technology is a sign of hope, a promise that a better digital world is possible.  
God's covenant with Noah, symbolized by the rainbow, was a promise never to destroy the earth by flood again. It represented a new relationship between God and humanity. Similarly, we envision a new covenant for the digital age – one where technology serves humanity and honors God, rather than enslaving or diminishing us.  
As Noah and his family were tasked with repopulating and stewarding the renewed earth, we are called to populate the digital world with technologies, practices, and communities that reflect God's love and wisdom. We are to be digital cultivators, tending the garden of our renewed technological landscape.  
Remember, Noah's ark wasn't just for him and his family. It preserved life for the entire planet. In the same way, our work in creating humane technology isn't just for ourselves or even just for the Church – it's for the benefit of all humanity.  
Like Noah, we may face doubt, ridicule, or seeming impossibilities. The task before us is enormous. But also like Noah, we work in faith, knowing that our labor is not in vain. We are building for a future we may not fully see, planting seeds that may germinate long after we're gone.  
In this final module, as we prepare to 'disembark' from this course and step into our calling, let us embrace the spirit of Noah. Let us be ready to build, to plant, to preserve what is good, and to courageously shape a new world. For we are not just passive passengers in this digital deluge, but active co-creators with God, called to steward technology for the flourishing of all creation."  
This narrative integrates our learning objectives by emphasizing Christian stewardship of technology, the need for faith-driven action, the importance of community, the value of small wins (seeds of change), and the vision of a technology landscape transformed by Kingdom values. It encourages students to see themselves as part of a greater story and calling, much like Noah, preparing them to act boldly in shaping the future of technology.

### Conclusion

### Application 

Let's break down the practical applications into three sections, focusing on resource utilization, coordination, and ecumenical efforts:

For the Individual:

Personal Audit: Conduct a "digital discipleship" audit of your own tech habits and skills. Identify areas where you can better align your digital life with your faith.  
Skill Sharing: Offer your tech skills to your local church or faith community. This could involve helping with website design, social media management, or digital literacy classes for seniors.  
Interfaith Dialogue: Engage in online interfaith dialogues about technology ethics, seeking to understand diverse perspectives while sharing your Christ-centered approach.  
Continuous Learning: Commit to ongoing education about the intersection of faith and technology. Follow Christian tech blogs, attend webinars, or join online study groups.  
Digital Sabbath: Implement a regular "digital Sabbath" to model healthy tech habits and deepen your spiritual practices.

For Our Church:

Tech Stewardship Team: Establish a "Technology Stewardship" team in your church to assess and guide the congregation's use of technology.  
Resource Mapping: Create a database of tech skills within your congregation. Use this to match needs with abilities, reducing reliance on external, often costly, services.  
Digital Missions: Develop a "digital missions" strategy, using technology to extend your church's outreach and support global partners more efficiently.  
Ethical Tech Policy: Draft a church-wide ethical technology use policy, grounded in biblical principles and humane tech concepts.  
Intergenerational Mentoring: Pair tech-savvy youth with older members for mutual learning \- tech skills exchanged for life wisdom.  
Open-Source Ministry Resources: Commit to creating and sharing open-source ministry resources (like curriculum or management tools) with other churches.

For Ecumenical Gatherings:

Ecumenical Tech Summits: Organize or participate in regular ecumenical "Faith and Technology" summits, bringing together diverse Christian traditions to address common challenges.  
Shared Resource Platform: Develop a cross-denominational online platform for sharing tech resources, best practices, and case studies of successful digital ministry initiatives.  
United Advocacy: Form an ecumenical coalition to advocate for ethical tech policies at local and national levels, presenting a united Christian voice on issues like data privacy, AI ethics, and digital equality.  
Collaborative Innovation: Establish an ecumenical "Christian Innovation Lab" where technologists from various traditions can collaborate on projects that serve the broader Body of Christ.  
Interfaith Tech Ethics Council: Initiate or join an interfaith council on technology ethics, bringing Christian perspectives into dialogue with other faith traditions on pressing tech issues.  
Global Digital Missions Coordination: Create a coordination body for global digital missions efforts to prevent duplication and enhance collaboration across denominations.  
Ecumenical Digital Literacy Program: Develop a comprehensive digital literacy program that can be adapted and used across different Christian traditions, especially serving underprivileged communities.

By focusing on these areas, we can better steward our resources, foster unity in the body of Christ, and present a more coherent Christian witness in the face of exponential technological change. This approach acknowledges our common ground in Christ while respecting denominational differences, and positions the Church to be a leading voice in shaping a more humane technological future.
